title: Nigel Slater’s recipe for baked celeriac, parsnips, tomatoes
summary:

paragraphs: Peel 750g of celeriac and cut it into thin slices – you want them to be about the thickness of a £1 coin. Do the same with 450g of parsnips.

Heat 3 tbsp of olive oil in a shallow pan over a moderate heat, then add as many of the celeriac and parsnip slices as you get in a single layer. Let them colour lightly, then turn them over with kitchen tongs. When both sides are golden, lift them out into a mixing bowl. Repeat with the remaining celeriac and parsnip slices. Set the oven at 200C/gas mark 6.

Peel and finely slice 2 medium-sized onions. In the same pan you used for the root vegetables, fry the onions in a little more oil until pale gold and translucent. As the onions start to soften, peel and thinly slice 2 cloves of garlic and add it to the onions. Slice 200g of cherry tomatoes in half.

In a baking dish, layer up the onions and garlic with the parsnips and celeriac, seasoning each layer with salt, pepper and a sprinkling of thyme leaves, and tucking in the tomatoes as you go. Pour over 500ml of hot vegetable stock and bake in the oven for 30 minutes. Serves 2

I use a 22cm round baking dish for this recipe. Giving the ingredients time to cook slowly in the aromatics and stock, this is a good way to use up the last of the winter roots before the first spring vegetables arrive. The recipe can be used as a side or as a principal dish. Offer a spoon for scooping up the thyme-scented cooking juices.

Swede works well in this dish, too, as does kohlrabi. You could nod to spring a bit by adding a few wild garlic leaves, pushed down into the hot juices as the dish comes from the oven. They will soften in the stock.
